title: Launch Roundup: scrubs deny SpaceX its 100 Falcon launch goal; look to end the year with a 300th mission milestone
summary: This week nearly saw two secret spaceplanes launched within days of each other. After ground systems concerns and then weather delays, the US Department of Defense’s X-37B vehicle had its OTV-7 launch on the Falcon Heavy USSF-52 mission scrubbed from its initial planned attempt on Dec. 11. Starlink Group 6-34 was also scrubbed that same day and again a day later due to high-level ground winds, during what turned out to be quite a volatile week for planned launches.

title: Blue Origin’s New Shepard Back in Business
summary: Blue Origin’s New Shepard suborbital rocket is back in business today, more than 15 months after a failure grounded all launches. The company markets New Shepard both to take passengers […]

title: Wallonia brings in Europe’s investment arm to boost space industry
summary: The European Investment Bank has agreed to explore the funding and advisory support needed to transform Belgium's southern region Wallonia into a space powerhouse.

title: New Shepard Returns to Flight
summary: After over a year of waiting, New Shepard has returned to flight. Following a scrubbed launch on the 18th, New Shepard cleared the tower flying the NS-24 mission on December 19th at 10:43 AM. The flight carried 33 experimental payloads, ranging from student projects to NASA-funded research, to the edge of space and back again. Both the Propulsion Module and Crew Capsule returned to the ground safely, and while there was no crew riding on this flight, the successful mission paves the way for a return to crewed flights in the near future.

title: US Congress recommends placing assets at Lagrange points to counter China
summary: “We’re in another space race back to the Moon, and this time it’s with China."
